Facebook Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg said she expects her company to find more instances of user data improperly shared with outside entities, a concession that comes as the social media giant is under fire for its handling of the trove of personal information Facebook users hand over to the company.

Asked why Facebook is only addressing issues related to Cambridge Analytica now when it was aware of the problem in December of 2015, Sandberg said her company had been given legal assurances that the user data in question was deleted but did not follow up to check and make sure that was the case.

The revelation that the data of so many users made its way into the hands of a third party has raised questions about how Facebook protects such data, prompting a wave of mea culpa interviews not just from Sandberg, but also from Facebook CEO and founder Mark Zuckerberg.

Facebook has been the subject of intense scrutiny in the wake of reports that Cambridge Analytica, a British data analytics firm used by President Donald Trump’s campaign, obtained the personal information of as many as 87 million Facebook users.

But she said she and Zuckerberg accept responsibility for the data breach that has prompted the current storm of controversy surrounding their company and that questions about their leadership are "hard questions" and "the right questions."

"I serve at the pleasure of Mark and our board, and I will be here as long as they think I'm the right person to run this and to lead our response, and to make sure that we can rebuild trust with people all over the world," she said.

The Facebook COO said questions about her and Zuckerberg's continued tenure leading the social media giant are up to the company's board of directors and to Zuckerberg himself, who is chairman of the company's board.
